videoSnippet.title: Just a Nezhmetdinov Game to Brighten Your Day :) | Part 1
videoSnippet.description:
#agadmator Just a Nezhmetdinov Game to Brighten Your Day :)

Rashid Gibiatovich Nezhmetdinov vs Yuri M Kotkov
17th RSFSR Ch (1957), Krasnodar, USSR 
Spanish Game: Berlin Defense. Rio Gambit Accepted

1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. O-O Ne4 5. Re1 Nd6 6. Ne5 Be7 7. Bd3 O-O 8. Nc3 Ne5 9. Re5 Bf6 10. Re3 g6 11. Qf3 Bg7 12. b3 Ne8 13. Ba3 d6 14. Rae1 Nf6 15. h3 Nd7 16. Nd5 f5 17. Nc7 Qc7 18. Qd5 Kh8 19. Re8 Nf6 20. Rf8 Bf8 21. Bb2 Bg7 22. Bc4 Bd7 23. Bf6 Bf6 24. Qf7 Qd8 25. Re8


Nezhmetdinov won a number of games against world champions such as Tal, against whom he had a lifetime plus score, and Spassky. He also had success against other world-class grandmasters such as Bronstein, Polugaevsky, and Geller. He achieved a plus score in the 20 games he contested against World Champions. But in addition to his aforementioned dismal score against Averbakh, he could only score +0âˆ’3=2 each against excellent defenders Petrosian and Korchnoi.
